relationships.evidence_text: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron Perry.
visiting with climate scientist Julian Struva.

relationships.target: National Snow and Ice Data Center
relationships.evidence_text: she became a senior research scientist at the National Snow and Ice Data Center, NSIDC.

relationships.target: Cooperative Institute for Research and Environmental Sciences
relationships.evidence_text: within the Cooperative Institute for Research and Environmental Sciences at the University of Colorado, Boulder.

evidence.target_surface: Cooperative Institute for Research and Environmental Sciences

relationships.evidence_text: More recently, she was a professor at the University College London.
recently was awarded a Canada Excellence Research Chair at the University of Manitoba.
her Arctic research interests are wide-ranging and include sea ice forecasting.
She has participated in several field campaigns in Greenland and the Arctic Ocean.

relationships.target: rapid environmental changes in the Arctic
relationships.evidence_text: trying to make sense of the rapid environmental changes being observed in the Arctic.

evidence.target_surface: rapid environmental changes in the Arctic

relationships.evidence_text: Dr. Struva's work has been featured in numerous magazines and news reports.
has given keynote addresses around the world on Arctic climate issues.
has briefed former vice president Al Gore.
Dr. Struva has published more than 80 articles in peer-reviewed journals.

relationships.target: national and international reports on climate change
relationships.evidence_text: has contributed to several national and international reports on climate change.

we had this paper in 2007 that we published.

when I spoke to Al Gore, it was in part because we had this paper.
if we just do business as usual and we keep letting greenhouse gases accumulate in the atmosphere.
we've had two publications since then, or actually more than two, I think four, on the topic.
that go into the IPCC reports.

one of the interests that Al Gore had was to talk about that

more concerning is their conservative in regards to the temperature sensitivity
the amount of ice you lose, particularly of global warming
how much ice you lose per metric ton of CO2 to the atmosphere
we'll see we're starting saying the first ice-free Arctic summers, probably in around 20-40s time frame
the models are now around 2050 on average for those first sort of instances of ice-free Arctic conditions
we have the least amount of sea ice in the Arctic Ocean that we've seen at this time of year
the value that we have right now is less than any amount we saw in the 1970s or in the 1980s or even the 1990s at this time of year
we're about six million square kilometers of sea ice in the Arctic Ocean at the moment
we have this long-term change because of warming that's happening
you were up living in the Arctic with a number of other scientists and folks from November of last year, 2019 through April of this year, 2020, on the Mosaic expedition
it's part of the German lead expedition
they froze their icebreaker into the ice for a full year
scientists, there's not one scientist that would be on the ship for a full year
they found an ice flow to decide that they were going to build a camp on. And they've just been letting the ship drift with that ice flow.
we each would take turns coming and going.
we were doing, you know, two month rotations was the plan.
we ended up there for four and a half months.
there's not one scientist that would be on the ship for a full year. So we each would take turns coming and going.
the ship that was being used to do the exchange between our leg and the next people coming in to take over was not well equipped to deal with winter ice conditions.
it burned up almost all of its fuel trying to get to the German ship Polar Stern.
we were stuck in the ice for a month, basically on that Russian ship because we had to get refueled.
They had to send another icebreaker to give us fuel so we could get home.
it was the first time I've experienced Polar night.
we were working in complete darkness for three months.
temperatures were typically minus 30 to minus 40.
I was pretty much responsible for instrumentation we put on the ice.
instruments that we have on satellites up in space.

the idea was to bring the same type of instrumentation on the ice flow so that we can look at things in more and a smaller scale and better understand how snow and ice properties and atmospheric properties influence the retrievals.
when we use satellites to monitor changes that are happening on the planet.
that really depends on how that energy interacts with the medium that is going through.
we had a full suite of instruments, we put on the ice.

evidence.target_surface: energy emitted in the microwave portion of the electromagnetic spectrum

relationships.evidence_text: one of the reasons why microwave is so useful for monitoring places like the polar regions is that it can see through the clouds.
if you have cloud cover. So then you can't see the surface.
we had a lot of equipment failures.
I think I spent most of my time troubleshooting instruments.
But I did get some good data collected.
the European Space Agency is considering building a satellite with those same frequencies on it.
the data I collected is very useful to decide whether or not this data could really inform us and help us simultaneously retrieve both how thick the ice is and how much snow is on the ice.
I've already submitted my first paper just sort of highlighting what the radar that I brought specifically for the expedition could do.
the radar that I brought specifically for the expedition could do.
It was a $600,000 rate that I had built by processing in the US.
because it measured at two different frequencies, which are used for measuring sea ice thickness.
I think I spent most of my time troubleshooting instruments.
I think we had between 80, 90 or so people on board.
that was a mix of scientists and crew.
you always really get bonded to people on an expedition because you can't go anywhere.
we went from this environment, this very social environment where we're playing and working with like 80 people to like complete lockdown.
None of us wanted to be home because even when you're on a ship like that, the things that you might miss...we couldn't do them when we came home because of COVID.
No, so my residence is in London. So I went back to London first.
our ship was able to dock a Norway and then to Germans, I'm chartered an airplane for us to fly home to our respective countries.
I didn't get to see any friends because everybody was really taken the lockdown seriously.
you didn't realize maybe how serious it was because we were detached from it all.
all of us were healthy because we left for the Arctic before COVID had come about.
Germans, I'm chartered an airplane for us to fly home to our respective countries.
I went back to the UK and then yeah, and then I didn't get to see any friends...

we could just stay in the Arctic. It's the best place for us to be right now.
and then we started seeing things emerging in Italy.
we would just get these international news clips every day that the Germans would kind of download for us.
I'd see the stuff out of China and that China was locked down.
I know that you and I have first crossed paths gosh, many years ago.
because we both at that time resided in the Boulder, Netherlands area.
turns out we have two kids each of similar ages.
your son is the same exact age to the day as my daughter, my oldest.
we've also kept in touch around climate.
we have a number of colleagues and organizations in common that we collaborate with in various ways.
you're not only are conducting science, but you're also speaking to the general public.
around the data and the potential impacts that you're seeing.

think it's false, think it's fake news or what have you.

when I would get on airplanes, um, traveling for business.
they would always ask me if I believed it.
they understand that there's going to be some serious implications of this climate shift that we're going through.

that had become our poster child for climate.
they understand that there's going to be some serious implications of this climate shift

every time we were on the ice, we had to have a polar bear guard with us.
being a polar bear guard is very challenging because you can't see it, you know, it's dark. And it's very cold.
people would do like two hour rotations of being a polar bear guard.
a bear came to our remote sensing instruments.
just moved one of the antennas into a different direction.
he actually stepped over all of our strings or cables that we had.
we kept a surveillance camera on the hut that would go off every five minutes to just monitor the stability of the site.
if a storm were to come and the ice were to diverge.
we didn't want to lose our instruments into the water.
we flipped through the surveillance camera footage and found the bear.

relationships.relationship: did not cause much damage to

we flipped through the surveillance camera footage and found the bear.

they started putting gasoline on all their cables.
the foxes tend to follow the bears and eat their, they just gavinch.

we can change how much we travel, you know, how we interact.

now they're going to invest like 12 million into bike lanes and encouraging people to bike.
everybody started biking.
we kind of like this change of pace and get being more physically active by using our bicycles instead of getting in our cars.
people were hanging out with each other and everybody was picking in the parks.
it's like, actually, it's really nice.
we're not thinking that climate change is like COVID, you're not thinking you're going to die this year.
